content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice one! Would be nice for shortest :P

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear statement. Interesting problem for both shortest and fastest.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Appropriate both for fastest and shortest

I do not know. Actually there are integer variables, so I cannot see here a calculus problem. However an analytical solution should exist. The straight forward strategy is to make a and d as small as possible and c and  d as big as possible.

Brute force approach in python take half a second for s = 49. Whats the time limit for clash? 

Precalculation all possibilities take 3s on external web editor

Thank you for the comment. I measured time of the brute-force algorithm from default solution for s=49 several times. It was always below 0.01s. Usually 7ms. In gdbonline web-editor the python algorithm takes 0.01 s for s=49. So execution time should not be a problem.

Could you compare your brute force algorithm with the default one? Is it the same?

I could not find anything about maximum execution time in online documentation. However in my experiments, I am getting the value of 6 seconds for the limit.
I was printing execution time to debug output in the main loop each 10 iterations for larger s values. For s = 400, I was getting execution times below 5 seconds. For s = 450, I get following error message:
Process has timed out. This may mean that your solution is not optimized enough to handle some cases.
I've forgotten how to take partials, but I'm fairly sure that answer must be an inflection point.
